SEARCH
Package uk.ac.leedsbeckett.oop

Class Vehicle

java.lang.Object
uk.ac.leedsbeckett.oop.Vehicle
Direct Known Subclasses:
Carriage, Locomotive
public abstract class Vehicle extends Object
Abstract base class for all vehicles that can move on railway tracks.

This is an ABSTRACT CLASS - you cannot create a Vehicle directly, only its subclasses like Locomotive and Carriage. Think of this as a blueprint that defines what ALL vehicles must have and be able to do.

Key Concepts for Beginners:

  • Abstract Class: A class that cannot be instantiated (created) directly. You must create a subclass like Locomotive or Carriage instead.
  • Inheritance: Locomotive and Carriage "inherit" from Vehicle, meaning they automatically get all the fields and methods defined here.
  • Master-Slave Pattern: Vehicles can be linked together in a chain. The front vehicle is the "master" and pulls the vehicles behind it (the "slaves" or "attached vehicles").

This class handles:

  • Position tracking: where the vehicle is on the grid
  • Orientation: which direction the vehicle is facing (NORTH, SOUTH, EAST, WEST)
  • Smooth animation: moving gradually between grid cells using pixel offsets
  • Vehicle coupling: attaching vehicles together in a train
  • Derailment: what happens when a vehicle goes off the track
See Also:
  • Locomotive
  • Carriage

  • Constructor Details

    • Vehicle

      protected Vehicle(GameWorld world, Position initialPosition, Orientation initialOrientation)
      Creates a new vehicle in the specified game world.

      This is a PROTECTED constructor, which means only subclasses (Locomotive, Carriage) can call it. The constructor validates that the vehicle is being placed on a valid track.

      Parameters:
      world - the game world containing the railway tracks and signals
      initialPosition - the starting grid position on a track (must be a valid track cell)
      initialOrientation - the initial direction the vehicle is facing (NORTH, SOUTH, EAST, or WEST)
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the initial position is not on a track, or if the track doesn't connect in a direction compatible with the orientation

    • Vehicle

      protected Vehicle(GameWorld world, int x, int y, Orientation initialOrientation)
      Creates a new vehicle in the specified game world using coordinates.
      Parameters:
      world - the game world containing the railway tracks and signals
      x - the starting x position on the grid
      y - the starting y position on the grid
      initialOrientation - the initial direction the vehicle is facing (NORTH, SOUTH, EAST, or WEST)
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the initial position is not on a track, or if the track doesn't connect in a direction compatible with the orientation

    • Vehicle

      protected Vehicle(GameWorld world, Position initialPosition, Orientation initialOrientation, boolean validatePosition)
      Creates a new vehicle in the specified world, optionally skipping position validation.

      This constructor is useful when creating a vehicle that will be attached to another vehicle. In this case, we use a "dummy" position temporarily, which will be corrected when the vehicle is attached using the attachVehicle() method.

      Example use case: Creating a carriage that will be attached to a locomotive. We don't know the final position yet, so we skip validation.

      Parameters:
      world - the game world containing the railway tracks
      initialPosition - the starting position (may be a temporary/dummy position if validatePosition is false)
      initialOrientation - the initial direction the vehicle is facing
      validatePosition - if true, validates that the position is on a valid track; if false, skips validation (use when position will be set later)
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if validatePosition is true and the initial position is not on a track or if the track is incompatible with the orientation

    • Vehicle

      protected Vehicle(GameWorld world, int x, int y, Orientation initialOrientation, boolean validatePosition)
      Creates a new vehicle in the specified world using coordinates, optionally skipping validation.
      Parameters:
      world - the game world containing the railway tracks
      x - the starting x position on the grid
      y - the starting y position on the grid
      initialOrientation - the initial direction the vehicle is facing
      validatePosition - if true, validates that the position is on a valid track
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if validatePosition is true and the initial position is not on a track or incompatible with the orientation

  • Method Details

    • inferOrientationFromTrack

      protected static Orientation inferOrientationFromTrack(GameWorld world, Position position)
      Determines a default orientation based on the track at the supplied position.

      Horizontal tracks default to EAST, vertical tracks default to NORTH. If the track supports multiple orientations (such as corner or junction tracks), EAST is preferred. If no track exists at the position, the world/position are null, or no compatible connections are found, EAST is returned and the caller's normal validation will still reject invalid positions. This helper is protected for subclasses to reuse when offering simplified constructors, keeping the inference logic scoped to the vehicle hierarchy.

      Parameters:
      world - the game world containing tracks
      position - the position to inspect
      Returns:
      a default orientation compatible with the track

    • getCellPosition

      public Position getCellPosition()
      Gets the current grid cell position of the vehicle.

      The railway is divided into a grid of cells. This method returns which cell the vehicle is currently in (e.g., row 3, column 5).

      Note: Due to pixel offset, the vehicle might be partially in the next cell during animation, but this returns the "main" cell it occupies.

      Returns:
      the grid position of the cell the vehicle is currently in

    • getOrientation

      public Orientation getOrientation()
      Gets the current orientation (direction) the vehicle is facing.

      Possible values are:

      • NORTH - pointing up
      • SOUTH - pointing down
      • EAST - pointing right
      • WEST - pointing left
      Returns:
      the orientation (direction) the vehicle is currently facing

    • getPixelOffset

      public int getPixelOffset()
      Gets the pixel offset within the current cell.

      This is used for smooth animation. Instead of jumping from cell to cell, vehicles move gradually. The offset tells us how far (in pixels) the vehicle has moved from the cell's starting position toward the next cell.

      Example: If the offset is 16, the vehicle is halfway through the cell (since CELL_PIXELS = 32).

      Returns:
      the number of pixels the vehicle has moved within the current cell (0 to 31)

    • isDerailed

      public boolean isDerailed()
      Checks if the vehicle has derailed (gone off the track).

      A vehicle derails when it tries to move where there is no track, or if it collides with another vehicle. A derailed vehicle cannot move until the simulation is reset or the vehicle is placed back on the track.

      Returns:
      true if the vehicle is derailed, false if the vehicle is on the track

    • setDerailed

      public void setDerailed(boolean derailed)
      Sets the derailed status of the vehicle.

      This method is used to manually mark a vehicle as derailed or to clear the derailment (put it back on track). Typically used by the game engine when detecting collisions or track violations.

      Parameters:
      derailed - true to mark the vehicle as derailed, false to clear derailment and allow movement again

    • moveForwardInstant

      public void moveForwardInstant()
      Instantly moves the vehicle forward one cell in its current orientation.

      "Forward" means in the direction the vehicle is facing. For example, if the vehicle is facing EAST, it will move one cell to the right.

      This is an "instant" move - no smooth animation, the vehicle jumps directly to the next cell.

      Throws:
      MovementException - if the move is not allowed (no track, red signal, out of bounds, etc.)

    • moveBackwardInstant

      public void moveBackwardInstant()
      Instantly moves the vehicle backward one cell (opposite to its orientation).

      "Backward" means opposite to the direction the vehicle is facing. For example, if the vehicle is facing EAST, it will move one cell to the WEST.

      This is an "instant" move - no smooth animation, the vehicle jumps directly to the previous cell.

      Throws:
      MovementException - if the move is not allowed (no track, red signal, out of bounds, etc.)

    • updateTrackOccupancy

      protected void updateTrackOccupancy(Position oldPos, Position newPos)
      Updates which track cells know about this vehicle's presence.

      Each track cell can "remember" which vehicle is on it. This method:

      1. Tells the old track cell: "this vehicle is leaving"
      2. Tells the new track cell: "this vehicle is now here"

      This is important for collision detection and preventing multiple vehicles from occupying the same cell.

      Parameters:
      oldPos - the position being vacated (can be null if vehicle is being created)
      newPos - the position being occupied (can be null if vehicle is being removed)

    • resetToPosition

      public void resetToPosition(Position newPosition, int newPixelOffset, Orientation newOrientation)
      Resets this vehicle to a specific position with proper track occupancy updates.

      This method is used when the user clicks the "Reset" button to restore all vehicles to their starting positions. It ensures that track occupancy is correctly updated.

      Parameters:
      newPosition - the grid position to reset to
      newPixelOffset - the pixel offset to reset to (usually 0)
      newOrientation - the orientation (direction) to reset to

    • stepAnimation

      public void stepAnimation(int delta)
      Animates the vehicle by the specified number of pixels for smooth movement.

      This is the core method for smooth animation. Instead of jumping from cell to cell, the vehicle moves a few pixels at a time. When the pixel offset reaches 32 (CELL_PIXELS), the vehicle automatically moves to the next cell.

      How it works:

      • Positive delta: move forward (in the direction the vehicle is facing)
      • Negative delta: move backward (opposite to the direction the vehicle is facing)
      • When pixelOffset reaches 32, vehicle moves to next cell and offset resets to 0

      Note: Derailed vehicles cannot move and will do nothing when this method is called.

      Parameters:
      delta - the number of pixels to move (positive = forward, negative = backward)
      Throws:
      MovementException - if movement to the next/previous cell is blocked by lack of track, red signal, or world boundary

    • checkMoveAllowed

      protected void checkMoveAllowed(Position from, Position to, Orientation dir)
      Checks if movement from one position to another is allowed.

      This is a PROTECTED method - it can be used by this class and its subclasses. It validates several conditions before allowing movement:

      1. Is the target position within the world boundaries?
      2. Is there a track at both the source and target positions?
      3. Do the tracks connect in the right direction?
      4. Is there a red signal blocking the movement?
      5. For switches, is the switch set to allow this movement?
      Parameters:
      from - the source position (where the vehicle currently is)
      to - the target position (where the vehicle wants to go)
      dir - the direction of movement (NORTH, SOUTH, EAST, or WEST)
      Throws:
      MovementException - if the movement is not allowed for any reason

    • setOrientation

      public void setOrientation(Orientation newOrientation)
      Sets the orientation (direction) of the vehicle.

      The vehicle can only face a direction that is compatible with the track it's on. For example, if the track only connects NORTH and SOUTH, you can't set the orientation to EAST or WEST.

      When is this used? When the vehicle goes around a corner or through a junction, it needs to change direction to follow the track.

      Parameters:
      newOrientation - the new direction to set (NORTH, SOUTH, EAST, or WEST)
      Throws:
      IllegalStateException - if the vehicle is not currently on a track
      IllegalArgumentException - if the track at the current position is incompatible with the new orientation (e.g., trying to face EAST on a NORTH-SOUTH track)

    • attachVehicle

      public void attachVehicle(Vehicle slave)
      Attaches a slave vehicle to this vehicle, forming a train.

      This implements the "master-slave" pattern. This vehicle becomes the "master" and the attached vehicle becomes the "slave". When the master moves, the slave automatically follows it.

      How it works:

      1. The method tries to find a valid track position behind this vehicle
      2. It checks multiple adjacent cells to find one with valid track
      3. It ensures no other vehicle is already occupying that position
      4. It sets up the master-slave relationship between the two vehicles

      Example: Attaching a Carriage to a Locomotive to form a train.

      Parameters:
      slave - the vehicle to attach (cannot be null, cannot already have a master)
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if slave is null or already has a master vehicle
      IllegalStateException - if this vehicle already has an attached vehicle (only one can be attached directly)
      IllegalStateException - if no valid track position is available adjacent to this vehicle

    • detachVehicle

      public Vehicle detachVehicle()
      Detaches the slave vehicle from this vehicle.

      This breaks the master-slave relationship. After detaching, the slave vehicle becomes independent and won't follow this vehicle anymore.

      Example: Detaching the last carriage from a train.

      Returns:
      the detached vehicle, or null if no vehicle was attached

    • getAttachedVehicle

      public Vehicle getAttachedVehicle()
      Gets the slave vehicle attached to this vehicle.

      This is a GETTER method - it simply returns the value of the attachedVehicle field.

      Returns:
      the attached vehicle (the one following this vehicle), or null if no vehicle is attached

    • getMasterVehicle

      public Vehicle getMasterVehicle()
      Gets the master vehicle this vehicle is attached to.

      If this vehicle is being pulled by another vehicle (like a carriage being pulled by a locomotive), this method returns that master vehicle.

      Returns:
      the master vehicle (the one pulling this vehicle), or null if this vehicle is not attached to anything

    • tick

      public void tick()
      Called each game tick to update the vehicle state.

      A "tick" is one update cycle of the game (like one frame in a video game). This method is called repeatedly, many times per second, to update the vehicle.

      What this method does:

      • Checks if the master vehicle has moved to a new cell
      • If yes, calls followMaster() to move this vehicle too
      • Updates the last known master position

      Subclasses can override: Locomotive overrides this to add movement logic.

    • followMaster

      protected void followMaster()
      Moves this vehicle to follow its master vehicle.

      This is a PROTECTED method - it can be called by this class and its subclasses.

      How following works:

      1. Calculate which direction to move (toward master's last position)
      2. Set the vehicle's orientation to face that direction
      3. Move forward one cell

      If the movement fails (no track, obstacle, etc.), the vehicle stays in place rather than crashing the program.
